Answer: I’m not sure why you think there would be a significant difference between a “super computer” and the device in your pocket. Most modern super computers are just large networks of fairly normal computers. They may be repackaged so that in the space of a desktop computer, you might have 100’s of individual computers. A super computer is not necessarily faster at performing a calculation, however, it can perform a multitude of those calculations simultaneously. To achieve this type of performance, an individual problem must be broken down into many little tasks. The smaller the tasks, the more cI’m not sure why you think there would be a significant difference between a “super computer” and the device in your pocket. Most modern super computers are just large networks of fairly normal computers. They may be repackaged so that in the space of a desktop computer, you might have 100’s of individual computers. A super computer is not necessarily faster at performing a calculation, however, it can perform a multitude of those calculations simultaneously. To achieve this type of performance, an individual problem must be broken down into many little tasks. The smaller the tasks, the more can be done simultaneously. So, apart from the computer language, and the OS, the only limit to string length is the available memory. On a super computer, this depends on what resources have been allocated to a specific task and is probably much lower than you might think. On the flip side, individual CPUs in a super computer could potentially have large amounts of RAM and that would be its maximum limit. You would probably have more contiguous RAM in a tricked-out gaming computer.One last thought; a text file is basically just a string stored in the file system. So, the maximum file size might be another limit.

Answer: As strange as this may sound, I would ask him a couple of questions about his spatial intelligence and off-the-ball work :1- How much of it is learned and developed ?2- Mid-game, to what degree are his moves calculated ?For the first part, I have zero doubt that Ronaldo had a god-given gift in terms of spatial intelligence, a huge head start in that regard, if you will. That’s actually the main point I will make when talking about how much ‘natural talent’ CR7 had, because there’s absolutely no chance his level of spatial intelligence was developed from scratch. What am I curious about is exacAs strange as this may sound, I would ask him a couple of questions about his spatial intelligence and off-the-ball work :1- How much of it is learned and developed ?2- Mid-game, to what degree are his moves calculated ?For the first part, I have zero doubt that Ronaldo had a god-given gift in terms of spatial intelligence, a huge head start in that regard, if you will. That’s actually the main point I will make when talking about how much ‘natural talent’ CR7 had, because there’s absolutely no chance his level of spatial intelligence was developed from scratch. What am I curious about is exactly how much of it is natural and how much is developed or trained, and whether he just realized his extraordinary gift and learned how to use it or he actually improved his spatial intelligence through any sort of training.As for the second part, let me explain the ‘mystery’ this way :On one hand, with how incredibly consistent he is with it, with how adaptive it is to surroundings (position and motion of the ball and the players, the available and created spaces… etc), and how effective it is at breaking and fooling even elite defenses and defenders, Ronaldo’s movement off-the-ball definitely looks like a product of impeccable calculation, the work of a genius.On the other hand, with how automatic it is (with respect to changes and such) and how he seems to have literally zero reaction/processing time with it, Ronaldo’s movement looks like an instinctive thing, basically a reflex for him (This apparently-contradictory combination is the scariest part of Ronaldo’s game. It’s the main reason why he’s a nightmare for any defense).What I would like to know is what it is like from Ronaldo’s POV : Does he feel like he actively processes things around him, but does it incredibly quickly ? Or does he feel as if there’s some sort of super computer in his brain that automatically processes everything for him in no time and forces his body to make the optimal move without Ronaldo consciously thinking about it (Tricky to express the idea, but I hope I did it will).All the other questions that would be interesting were probably already asked in past interviews.Follow my football Twitter account :

At this point, still totally plausible.-The science fiction fuckery comes-Humans have these 6 nifty body systems. They all work together and keep you alive and functioning. But do you know what happens if even one of them fails?You fucking die.-A disease doesn’t make you invincible. You’re still a living organism. The phrase “walking dead” is some mighty fine bullshit. You can’t walk if you’re dead. You’re fucking dead.Once one of those systems up there fails, the party’s over. You die, and turn into a sack of skin laying in the dirt.-There’s no halfway point. If they don’t get it, they turn into a sack of skin and bones laying in the dirt.They puncture a lung, they can’t breathe, and turn into a sack of skin and bones laying in the dirt.They tear a muscle, they can’t move, die of dehydration, and turn into a sack of skin and bones laying in the dirt.If they get a small cut, they get whatever myriad of diseases, they turn into a sack of skin and bones laying in the dirt.If they get a cut, and bleed too much, they die, and turn into a sack of skin and bone laying in the dirt.-Zombies are basically newborn babies in terms of health. He just, makes you like him. Makes you believe in him. Makes you utterly totally and completely of yoThe MuleSPOILERS FOR THE FOUNDATION NOVELS! IF YOU HAVEN’T READ THEM YET, AND WANT TO, STOP NOW!Yup, that guy, right there.The Mule is the primary antagonist of the Foundation novel, Foundation and Empire.What makes this little, rather unassuming person, dressed as a fool, so damn scary?The Mule is a mutant. A human being who has developed a single terrifying psychic power.He can make you like him.Specifically, he can reach into your head, and change a few things. It’s not really mind control. He just, makes you like him. Makes you believe in him. Makes you utterly totally and completely of your own will.. obedient.He can change who you are, on a fundamental level. He can make you betray everyone you have ever loved and anything you have ever believed in.There’s no resisting it, and once it’s done, you won’t want to anymore.And he can do it, en masse, on a planetary scale.He conquered the Galaxy in less than Five years.A lot of the other things on this list will torture you, and even kill you.. but this guy…He’ll change you. Make you someone completely different. Someone more to his liking.As a note, I know characters like this have appeared since, and some are even more powerful, but I don’t think there was anything quite like this guy before he came out, and there certainly nothing on the scale this guy is capable of. He always creeped me out, even when I first read the book.

question: https://www.quora.com/What-are-the-most-interesting-concepts-in-science-fiction

Answer: One overlooked aspect in spaceship design: Thermal management.Contrary to popular belief, space isn’t necessarily cold; if you’re standing next to a star, the space around is certainly going to be very hot.Space also does not have air. This means that the only way that heat can travel is through radiation, and radiation is the worst way to dissipate heat away. In addition to receiving ambient heat, spacecraft generate heat through many means, such as the operation of rocket engines, operation of electronics, or just the body heat of the crew members. Therefore, it needs radiators to dissipateOne overlooked aspect in spaceship design: Thermal management.Contrary to popular belief, space isn’t necessarily cold; if you’re standing next to a star, the space around is certainly going to be very hot.Space also does not have air. This means that the only way that heat can travel is through radiation, and radiation is the worst way to dissipate heat away. In addition to receiving ambient heat, spacecraft generate heat through many means, such as the operation of rocket engines, operation of electronics, or just the body heat of the crew members. Therefore, it needs radiators to dissipate excess heat and keep the temperature within acceptable levels. Let’s take a look at the ISS; these radiators are mounted outboard:If these radiators (or thermal management system) malfunction, the consequences can be devastating. The internal temperature can rise to a level that is dangerous to the occupant and/or damage equipment inside.But when you look at sci-fi spaceships, almost nobody talked about this aspect. Even if they do, it’s usually treated as an afterthought rather than a major driver to spacecraft design or part of the story. Instead of going through fancy battles, perhaps all you need to do to force an enemy spacecraft to surrender is to heat them up. Instead of getting lost in space, you could very well end up being roasted alive on the way.One major film that touched this is Avatar:Those big, glowing red thing in the back is the thermal management system, heated up so hot after a multi-year interstellar journey.
